OriginalText: Successfully completing missions will award you with additional funds and intel.
Funds: Use to purchase gear for your crew, and upgrade your aircraft.
Intel: As you gain more intel, you will unlock better gear for your crew & aircraft upgrades.
Each altitude holds different hazards, choose your altitude wisely!
In range of flak & anti-air guns
Some enemy fighters cannot reach high altitude!
Upgrade your crew's gear to better cope with conditions at mid/high altitude.
Above some flak & all anti-air guns
Out of range of all flak & anti-air guns

Your Bomb Aimer starts in the nose gun turret. Move your Bomb Aimer to the bomb aiming station to use the camera, operate the bomb bay doors, and release bombs.

Highly skilled bombers can see the target more clearly through clouds at higher altitudes.

The bomb bay doors rely on the hydraulic system to function.

Flying with the bomb bay doors open increases drag, using more fuel; it may also increase the chance of remaining bombs being shot, which could be disastrous!

Move your bomb aimer (or any member of your crew) to the Bomb Aimer's station.

To perform the bomb run:
Release when the target is centered in the bomb sight

The bomb bay doors rely on the hydraulic system to function.

On missions with multiple targets, arm only the bombs required for each target.

Available missions are displayed on the map. Select a mission to view more details.

Mission rewards (Intel and Funds) are shown on the mission board when a mission is selected.

Critical missions must be completed to progress the campaign.

Completing certain missions will award extra bonuses, which affect subsequent missions:
Equip your crew with new gear at the Crew Quarters.
Oxygen: Seconds of oxygen (when not at a station, at high altitude)
If your crew land or bail out in the sea or behind enemy lines, survival equipment will increase their chances of being rescued and returning home safely!

View your crew's unlocked abilities and train them with secondary skills in the Crew Training screen.

Secondary skills are unlocked for each member of your crew as they reach higher levels.
Your electrical system provides electricity to the radar and radio operator's station.

The Lancaster has four engines. You can continue to fly with just one engine, but ascending to higher altitudes will be slower and fuel usage will be less efficient.

You can send a member of your crew out onto the wings to repair broken down engines. It is recommended to fly steadily while crew are on the wings.
Engines that are on fire can be put out by:
Activating engine extinguishers (if installed) via the engineer's station
Sending a crew member to the wings with a fire extinguisher
If an engine fire is extinguished quickly enough, the engine will remain functional.
Your flight engineer can repair broken systems faster than the other members of your crew.

Your flight engineer can extinguish engine fires using built-in extinguishers (if installed), and pump fuel between the two fuel tanks.

The engineer's station displays current fuel usage, and an estimate of how long your fuel will last at this current usage rate.

A skilled flight engineer can also adjust the strength of the fuel mix, allowing you to fly faster (using more fuel) or slower (using less fuel) for a short duration.
You have limited fuel per mission, split between two fuel tanks. Fuel tanks can be damaged, causing them to leak.

In the event of a leaking fuel tank, your flight engineer can pump fuel to the other tank via the engineer's station panel.

A leaking fuel tank can be repaired by sending a member of your crew out onto the wing. Some upgraded fuel tanks are self sealing, so will only leak for a short duration when damaged.

Fuel usage will be higher than usual, when:
Landing gear down, or bomb bay doors open (due to resulting drag)
Aero surfaces are damaged or destroyed (due to resulting drag)

The Lancaster starts with 3 gun turrets- nose, tail and mid-upper. A ventral turret can be installed, beneath the aircraft.

Gun turrets are powered by the hydraulic system, so are unable to aim if it is broken.

Skilled gunners have better aim, and will be more efficient with their ammo usage.

Each turret has a limited amount of ammo. When this ammo is depleted, it can be re-stocked from the ammo box found towards the middle of the aircraft.
 
Any crew member can restock any turret- sometimes it may be easier to send another crew member to restock all the turrets, without your gunners leaving their seats.

Upgrade and customise your bomber at the hangar.

Your bomber has a maximum weight limit for new equipment. To increase this limit, allowing more upgrades to be installed, upgrade your engines.
Armour: Amount of damage that can be taken.
Weight: How much this equipment weighs.
Reliability: The less reliable a system is, the higher the chance that it will break down.

Some equipment can increase your crew's chance of survival in the event of crash landing in enemy territory or ditching in the sea. This will only affect crew who are within range of the bomber once it is down.
The hydraulic system provides power to:
The hydraulic system can be repaired if broken down.
You can send injured crew to the rest bed to recover health.
Your navigator plots your course to the mission objective, and helps you to spot ground targets.

Your navigator creates heading markers. Tag these markers to confirm your heading with your pilot.

Your navigator needs visibility of the ground in order to navigate well. Highly skilled navigators will navigate better with low visibility, and can even navigate by the stars.

With a skilled navigator, you can place a custom waypoint on the map to avoid upcoming hazards. Your navigator will mark hazards on the map as they are spotted, or when your radio op receives reconnaissance information.
Select a category from the left panel for more information.

The oxygen system supplies oxygen to your aircraft's stations.

At high altitude, your crew will use their personal oxygen supplies if:
They are not at a station
The oxygen system is broken down
If your oxygen system is functional, your crew's personal oxygen supplies re-fill when they are at their stations.

Recon Photos can be taken at the bomb aiming station.

It takes a highly skilled bomb aimer to take photos above low altitude, or through cloud- and even then, the chances of getting a good photo are lower in these conditions!

It's important to always have someone in the pilot's seat! 

Any of your crew can take over, but a skilled pilot will do the best job.

Your pilot will follow navigation markers, as you tag them.

Your pilot is in charge of the aircraft's altitude, landing gear and performing evasive manoeuvres.

If you decide that contuning the mission has become too risky, you can order your crew to plot a course back home with the pilot's 'Abort' order.

The pilot's “Bail Out” order will instruct your crew to grab parachutes and bail out (while there are sufficient parachutes).

To land at the airbase, ensure the landing gear is down.

Your radar system reveals enemy fighters and submarines, making them easier to tag.

The radar relies on the electrical system to function. A member of your crew must be at the radio operator station for the radar to be visible.

Upgraded radars have a faster sweep, and improved range.
Targets can be tagged without the radar, but they will be much more difficult to spot.

Your radio op operates the radar, which will make enemy fighters far easier to tag. 

An upgraded radar will increase how often green radar 'blips' are visible. Without the radar, your crew may lose track of tagged fighters if they go out of visible range.

Your Radar relies on the Electrical System to work.

A skilled radio op can:
Radio for recon: locations of some known hazards will be added to the map
Call Spitfires: a group of Spitfire fighters will come to support you for a duration
Auto Tag: tags any fighters that appear on the radar for a short duration

Select new recruits for your crew in the recruitment hut.

The tickboxes on the right hand side of the screen show you which roles are currently filled, and which ones need filling!
Tag navigation points created by your navigator to give your pilot a heading.
Tag enemy fighters to instruct your gunners to attack.
Tag bomb targets to start a bomb run.
Tag the airbase, on returning from a mission, to land.

The radar provides green radar 'blips' to help you spot fighters to tag, and your navigator provides orange dots to help you spot ground-based targets.

You can still tag enemy fighters without a radar, but they will be harder to spot (especially at night, or in cloudy weather).
When you select a member of your crew currently at a station, you will have access to the station controls!

Any member of your crew can perform any role, but someone skilled in a particular role will perform it better or more efficiently!

Examples:
Any of your crew can take the pilot's seat, but they will not fly as well as your pilot.
Any of your crew can repair broken systems, but a trained engineer will repair systems faster.
Any of your crew can be placed in gun turrets, but trained gunners will have better aim.
Additional abilities for each role, available at their stations, unlock as your crew level up!
